instruction: Summarize the key findings of the paper.
output: The paper finds that under open-access management, the debris stock in LEO can diverge to infinity, leading to Kessler Syndrome. The authors find that the average growth of returns to operating a satellite and the “orbital occupancy elasticity of satellite payoffs” are key economic parameters determining whether and when Kessler Syndrome occurs. The paper also provides a novel insight into the existence of an open-access equilibrium manifold due to couplings between satellites and debris in the collision risk function. The authors use a dynamic model with both economic and physical detail to estimate the time until Kessler Syndrome occurs under open-access management.
